RT @tom_pakenham@colinmckerrache Agreed it needs to be pointed out. Worth simultaneously acknowledging that infrastructure provision & user experience evolves along the S curve. That is, the fact that something needs improving for customer x in the future doesn’t mean it isn’t good enough for customer y now.

@TimMLatimer Thanks Tim, I think at this stage the best thing is to be humble and keep re-evaluating what's working and what's not. I'll try and post what we got right and wrong about 2020 soon.

@TimMLatimer Also worth noting that S curves are usually based on total addressable market, not annual sales. By that metric, we're still at less than 1%. But, autos are complicated because many people  never buy a new car. Lots to think about here.
@TimMLatimer That last part may be wrong. countries will probably 'build their way out' of any infrastructure constraint to take advantage of lower cost vehicles.

@TimMLatimer If it helps, we use a modified Norton Bass Diffusion model (fancy speak for an S-curve), from parity onwards (parity varies by country and segment) with p and q values calibrated on adoption leaders, and additional variables for housing stock/infrastructure in a given country.

This chart helps illustrate something I've been saying: 

-In an optimistic scenario, global light vehicle sales don't return to 2018 levels until around 2024
- 2021 EV sales should be around 4m. By 2024/25, ~10m, maybe higher 
- Conclusion: ICE vehicle sales have already peaked https://t.co/mNd87q4WpT

RT @JamesTFrith.@BloombergNEF's 2020 Battery Price Survey found average pack prices are $137/kWh, of which cells account for $102/kWh.

This represents a 74:26 split between the cell and pack. As more BEV specific platforms are introduced the cost contribution of the pack will diminish. https://t.co/rsoDU6mBf5

The full breakdown is only available to BNEF clients, but you can find a few more details here on the pack/cell split and different applications here. 
https://t.co/54AOBbaCAp

Congratulations to @JamesTFrith and team for the huge amount of work to gather all the data for this.

RT @joannakyriazisWhat does today's climate plan do for clean transportation? Thread.

One of the things I'm struck by in reading the latest climate plans from the UK and Canada is how much work, thought, and data have gone into developing a cohesive set of measures. Hats off to the civil service and related bodies in both places.

Looking through the list of investment areas, these all look very sensible. Big push on building efficiency which is great to see. 

https://t.co/zllC5WNHFi

Go Canada. This story makes me smile. https://t.co/WBTFqjjhs6

@Burdinski Yes, let's see how the targets breakdown by sector. 
In terms of overall CO2 reduction, the power sector has been doing most of the heavy lifting over the last 10 years.

This has very big implications for Europe's 2030 automotive CO2 standards. 
These are what's driving EV sales right now. Tightening the 2030 target from 37.5% reduction to +50% reduction will require much higher levels of EV adoption. https://t.co/g697nPFESY

Average range for BEVs models rose about 13% a year from 2012-19. 
My best guess here is that it keeps rising for another 3-5 years, plateaus for a while, and then starts to fall slightly as the charging network improves.

700km range and 200kW charging capability. EVs will keep getting better, and we're nowhere near the end of the road on this. 
https://t.co/wFsO4ZB0Up

@grecobs In BNEF's May 2020 outlook, our 2040 number was close to 60% of sales. But that will likely go up next year because of: China/Japan/Korea CO2 neutral target, Biden win, EU 2030 tightening, CA 2035 phase out, UK 2030 etc. All announced since that was published.

As companies set aggressive decarbonisation targets,  in some cases it is countries that need to keep up to stay competitive. https://t.co/gWkL4BcPAi

For example, hydrogen fuel cells may play a role for heavy duty long haul trucking, but for passenger cars, even if you doubled the FCV fleet every 2 years for the next two decades (hard!), they would still only be about ~2% of the vehicles on the road.

That will be hard and require large investments. Claiming otherwise underplays the scale of the challenge. But the point is that if you think that's not the right route, you need to propose an alternative or openly state that net zero is off the table.
Work back from any 2050 net zero target and you find that the vast majority of new vehicle sales need to be electric within about 10 years. https://t.co/7HNhCtOLbP

@gordonlaird7 I would put it this way: technology improvements, and a lot of people caring, are probably both individually necessary but insufficient conditions for achieving net zero.
The grid can manage all those EVs, says group whose job it is to manage said grid. https://t.co/UZEPzRBHf0
This is also one of the reasons why forecasting is such a fraught area. Because in everything from epidemics to climate change, human behaviour and ingenuity are still the biggest variables.

Reminder amid all the hot takes that there are real people working hard to improve the present and future of their country. 
If the U.K manages to get even close to net zero by 2050, it won't be because of technology magic, it will be because of hard work by people who care. https://t.co/Nf00La76d4

Thanks @CBC727, @energyequity , @EthanAll and Aleksandra O'Donovan for tracking all of these and more. Full list and analysis available to BNEF clients.

Biden talked about a target of installing 500,000 EV chargers, but with no specific timeline. Watch the American Transportation Infrastructure Act, that may be where the action is. 
Lastly, look for a ramp up in procuring EVs for the government fleet.

Biden has also called for electrification of all 500,000 school buses in the U.S. 
Kamala Harris sponsored the 'Clean School Bus Act', so watch for a push on this. The local air quality/health benefits could make it quite popular.

Also, a scrappage scheme favouring EVs. Biden's most likely approach here is to build on Senator Schumer's 'Clean Cars for America' proposal. This could be very big and would change the composition of the U.S. auto fleet.

Next up: the EV federal tax credit. This one would require support from the Senate. If that happens, The federal tax credit cap could be raised to 600,000 vehicles per automaker from 200,000 today. Biggest beneficiary: GM.
All eyes on what happens with the final Senate seats here

What does a Biden presidency mean for the U.S. EV market? 
For starters, strong fuel economy standards. 

Not clear where these will land yet, but Obama era fuel economy standards would require around 25% of U.S. light duty vehicle sales to be electric by 2026.
@MLiebreich Congratulations Michael! Hope you and the family are doing well.

The expansion of the congestion charge in London is cancelled. This is a bad move. Congestion charging works, and is one of the only near term ways to improve air quality.

Poor air quality is killing people and there is growing evidence that it makes Covid mortality rates worse. https://t.co/NsCKQRRCow

@AloysiusFekete Size plays a role too: UK and France are both at similar adoption levels, Germany a bit higher but that's likely due to the current very generous incentives. Also, lots of new EV model launches in 2020 and the RHD variants often get launched a bit later.

Poor urban air quality is killing people in many different ways. Tackling this means electrify all buses, delivery vans and ride hailing vehicles as quickly as possible.

And yes, we should all walk and cycle more.  These are not mutually exclusive ideas. https://t.co/h4CrRX2haf

That's a quick take, so don't hang your hat on it. I'll update this as more info becomes available.

This is mostly as expected. The draft changes were announced last year. Companies like Toyota will benefit from the hybrid rule changes. 
China is still aiming for around 25% of vehicle sales to be NEVs by 2025.

China has now extended the credit targets: 14% in 2021, 16% in 2022 and 18% in 2023. It has also changed how traditional hybrids are treated: they will no longer be counted the same as regular ICE vehicles. This reduces the number of EVs automakers need to sell to hit the targets

The NEV % required was set at 10% and 12% for 2019 and 2020, but each battery electric vehicle sold generates more than 1 credit, so actual share of sales required is much lower. Automakers can trade credits, but so far NEV credits have been oversupplied.

The NEV credit system applies to passenger vehicles. This is separate from the CAFC fuel economy regulations, but there is a mechanism to transfer excess credits between the two. CAFC is also tightening.

Background: the NEV credit system essentially requires automakers to sell a set percentage of battery electric, plug-in hybrid or fuel cell vehicles. The % is applied to the number of combustion vehicles they sell.
Quick thread on changes to China’s New Energy Vehicle credit system. This is an important piece of policy for the global EV market.

38. Direct road transport CO2 emissions drop in 2020, but then recover and continue growing until 2031 as the vehicle fleet mix slowly changes. More stringent fuel economy regulations for commercial trucks and other policy measures will be needed to bend the curve faster. https://t.co/1xfhj2yvyW

37. Oil demand from passenger vehicles is hit hard by Covid-19 and never recovers to 2019 levels. But growth in heavy commercial vehicles keeps overall road transport oil demand growing until 2031, when it starts to decline.

36. EVs across all segments are already displacing 1 million barrels of oil demand per day. Most of this is from two- and three-wheelers and buses in China. This rises to 17.6 million barrels of oil demand per day globally by 2040. https://t.co/dMl9Wjx3un
35. The combined EV electricity demand profile flattens as electrification spreads to new segments with different usage patterns, and as more charging options become available.

34. Globally, passenger EVs consume 1,290TWh, commercial EVs consume 389TWh, e-buses consume 216TWh and electric two-wheelers consume 69TWh by 2040. Combined, these add just 5.2% to global electricity demand in that year. https://t.co/jxvaSMDb5y

33. Fuel cell vehicle adoption will be geographically limited, with higher adoption rates in California, China, parts of Europe, Japan and South Korea. These are all regions with active plans for the deployment of hydrogen refueling infrastructure.

32. FCVs achieve higher adoption rates in commercial vehicles and buses. By 2040 FCVs account for 1.5% of the medium-duty truck sales, 3.9% of heavy-duty and 6.5% of municipal bus global annual sales.

31. Fuel cell vehicles represent just under 1% of the global passenger vehicle fleet in 2040. Even achieving this requires nearly a thousand-fold scale up from the 20,000 passenger FCVs on the road today, and a dramatic reduction in the cost of producing green hydrogen.

In several large markets, more than one third of commercial vehicles on the road – of any size – serving urban applications are electric or fuel cell by 2040.  The economics of this are already favorable for some use cases. https://t.co/hAMQ7W2aS1
30. Commercial EV adoption is driven by cities, as urbanization and e-commerce are leading to new efforts to reduce local pollution and improve the quality of living.
29. Road freight demand continues to grow to 2040, but the growth is uneven between segments and countries. Small vans and trucks increase in importance, with demand rising more than 50% by 2040.

28. Electric buses do not fully take over the market. Diesel and hydrogen fuel cell buses round out the rest of the fleet by 2040 in areas where installing charging infrastructure is difficult, where temperatures are extreme and near industrial hydrogen clusters.
27. Our e-bus forecast remains unchanged from last year, with e-buses comprising over 67% of the global bus fleet in 2040.

26. Supportive policies, rising manufacturer interest and rapidly improving economics will soon push two- and three-wheeler electrification significantly higher. In 2040, the electric two-wheeler sales share reaches 77%,

25. Some 30% of global two- and three-wheeler sales and 20% of the existing fleet are already electric. China accounts for the bulk of two-wheeler electrification to date, but sales are growing rapidly in markets like Taiwan, Vietnam and India. https://t.co/vS9vEMxGIG

24. Beyond passenger cars, several ‘killer apps’ are emerging for electrification in the 2020s: Two- and three-wheeled vehicles (scooters, mopeds, motorcycles, tuktuks and rickshaws) and municipal buses. Delivery vans and ride-hailing vehicles are the next segments to tip.

23. Fully autonomous vehicles begin to impact global auto markets, but not the mid 2030s. Total kilometers traveled go electric faster than the fleet, because EVs are operated at higher utilizations. https://t.co/EOCngFdQQj
22. Despite the dip from Covid-19, shared mobility plays a growing role, reaching 16% of all road kilometers traveled in 2040, from around 5% in 2019.

21. Many of these are aspirational targets and it is not clear how they will be implemented, but a few are starting to receive legal backing. The 13 countries with targets represent 13% of global auto sales in 2019. Our forecast does not assume any of their targets are met.
20. 13 countries and 31 municipalities or regions have announced targets for phasing out sales of new internal combustion vehicles, mostly by 2030 or 2040.

19. This means about 31% of the world's passenger cars are electric - but some regions go much higher, with China and parts of Europe at over 50%. In 2040, there are still more km driven globally by internal combustion passenger vehicles than EVs.
18. By 2040 there are just under 500 million passenger EVs on the road, out of a total passenger vehicle fleet of 1.6 billion.
17. Sales of internal combustion passenger vehicles peaked in 2017 and are in permanent decline, but the fleet keeps growing until 2030.

16. The motorization rate still rises steadily in India and other emerging markets, but this rise is not enough to offset the demographic-driven sales declines in mature auto markets, or offset the trends of more urbanization and more shared mobility.
15. Passenger vehicle sales peak in 2036 and never cross the symbolic 100 million per year mark. https://t.co/vrcX0EWcfx
14. PHEVs represent 28% of global passenger plug-in vehicle sales in 2025 and 26% in 2030, but their share drops quickly in the 2030s as battery electric vehicles (BEVs) continue to get cheaper.
13. Plug-in hybrids account for a larger share of our short-term forecast than in the past, in particular in Europe as automakers push to meet the 2030 vehicle CO2 targets.

12. The U.S. falls further behind leading EV markets over the next few years, but catches up in the 2030s. Nearly 60% of U.S. households have two or more cars – and many have the ability to install home charging – making them ideal adopters as EV economics and range improve.
11. Automakers focus their passenger EV efforts on the markets with the most stringent regulations for the next 10 years, leading to low rates of EV adoption in the Rest of World category.

10. China and Europe combined represent 72% of all passenger EV sales in 2030, driven by European vehicle CO2 regulations and China’s EV credit system, fuel economy regulations and city policies restricting new internal combustion vehicle sales. https://t.co/xn6Ck2jIrM

9. Until parity is reached, policy support is still required in most markets. Sales rise quickly thereafter, but charging infrastructure availability starts to constrain the market in the 2030s, for people without access to home or workplace charging options.
8. The first segment (large cars in Europe) crosses by 2022, while small vehicles in India and Japan do not hit parity until after 2030 due to very low average purchase prices in these segments.
7. Price parity between EVs and internal combustion vehicles is reached by the mid-2020s in most segments, but there is a wide variation between geographies. https://t.co/M1utxnxYfB

6. By 2025, EVs hit 10% of global passenger vehicle sales, rising to 28% in 2030 and 58% in 2040. Some markets achieve much higher penetrations, but low adoption in emerging markets reduces the global average.
5. The long-term outlook for EVs remains bright, as fundamental cost and technology improvements outweigh the short-term impacts of the pandemic.
4. The pandemic highlights the value many people place on private car ownership during times of crisis. Privately owned cars are not going away anytime soon.

3. EV share of global sales is relatively flat in 2020 at around 3%, but then continues rising and hits 7% in 2023 with sales of around 5.4 million. Some automakers delay EV launches in North America, but the timelines in Europe and China remain largely unchanged.

2. EV sales hold up better than combustion vehicles in most markets due to a backlog of orders, new models, and policy in Europe and China. Even so, they drop 18% to around 1.7 million in 2020. The shape of the recovery varies, with EV sales in China and Europe pulling ahead.

1. Passenger vehicle sales plunge 23% in 2020, EVs drop for the first time in the modern era.  Global auto sales do not recover to 2019 levels until 2025. Commercial vehicle sales also fall, but recover by 2022 due to e-commerce and growing freight demand in emerging economies.

Despite the name, EVO is our outlook for all of road transport. It starts with forecasting total movement of people and goods in the future. Then on to vehicle fleet sizes, sales and drivetrain mix across all vehicle segments, + impacts on energy, materials and infrastructure.

None of this means that the principles of consumer adoption don’t apply. They do. It just means this will be bumpy and for the next few years you probably can’t wave the s-curve wand just yet, or at least not reliably on a global basis. 
/end
Now, that’s contentious for autos because it’s a big purchase with a long lifetime and many people never buy a new car. Lots to think about here.

Another wrinkle: most consumer adoption diffusion theory is based on the whole population of buyers, not just buyers in that year. We’re still at under 1% of the total vehicle fleet (currently ~0.6%) ie: very much still in the Innovator phase.

So to do the short/medium term well, you have to go model by model (high, medium or low volume production intent?), region by region and policy by policy. We maintain a database of over 700 EV policies to help us do this, and track the EV plans of every automaker.
In an ideal policy world, you subsidize/support things right up to the point where organic demand takes over. But that almost never happens, it’s always messy. Given the stakes, that’s ok.

Why? Because in the short term, policy support is going to change. Direct subsidies get expensive beyond the first 3-4% of buyers, so most markets are moving to indirect measures (eg: fuel economy/CO2 regs) that force most automakers to cross subsidize their EVs.
But that doesn’t fully kick in until EVs hit price parity with their internal combustion counterparts. That’s still around 4-5 years out in most markets.

To do part of our long-term EV forecast at BNEF, we use a modified Norton Bass Diffusion model (fancy speak for an S curve). We add a bunch of extra parameters for availability of charging, affordability and other factors.

Short thread on s-curves: 
I often get asked about this, usually framed as “we’re about to hit the steep part of the s-curve, why is BNEF still only forecasting EVs (including plug-in hybrids) at 11% of global sales in 2025”

@JHildenMinton Hard to say. It's all of the above at once. There are certainly a lot of EVs sold there over the last five years that wouldn't stand a chance in western markets, but that's changing fast.

Finally, the government really doesn't seem to want EV sales to go down. Hence the softer landing. 
The government target of 5 million New Energy Vehicles (practically all EV, but a few FCV) on the road by 2020 is looking more likely. Don't bet against China on this.

Interestingly, the government is pushing harder on battery density and vehicle efficiency. There are new multipliers for these in place in the new subsidy regime. 
China is pushing the local industry hard towards more energy dense NMC batteries, and longer range vehicles.
There's a transition period. from now to June 11 the 2017 subsidies continue at 70% of their original rate. So no dramatic drop like past cuts.
The regional level subsidies remain in place. Earlier drafts had these removed which would have hit sales hard.  Shanghai has already announced its 2018 subsidy policy and others will follow.
Short range BEVs see their subsidies cut, but long range ones (+300km on NEDC) will actually see subsidies rise slightly.  PHEVs cut slightly, but only by 8%.
China cut EV subsidies last night. But it probably won't derail the growth there, and 2018 is still on track for sales of around 1 million. Short thread on why:
